speaker: Cory Booker
vclaim: "We now have longitudinal data showing that children born around Superfond sites have significantly higher rates of congenital defects, significantly higher rates of autism."
date: stated on April 29, 2019 in a cable TV news interview.:
title: The poker argument for environmental justice remains within the lines
text: As part of the major presidential campaign launched by Mr. Corey Booker, Democrats in New Jersey speak of "environmental justice" - which seems to mean addressing environmental factors that disproportionately affect low-income people and minority backgrounds. One of the issues that he highlights is the impact of so-called superfund sites and hazardous waste sites that are particularly prevalent in the State of Poker, usually located in the same neighbourhoods as low-income populations, often of African or Spanish origin. In an interview on 29 April with the Ministry of Public Health and Public Health, Booker raised this issue not only as a challenge to social justice and equality, but also as a public health problem. "We now have longitudinal data showing that children born around Superfond sites have significantly higher rates of congenital defects, significantly higher rates of autism," he said. This is not the first time poker has made this argument, and it probably won't be the last. So, we decided to dig up and see how he stood in the way of scrutiny. First, the press team sent us two studies: the 2008 paper on the correlation between toxic landfills and autism spectrum disorders and the 2011 study looking for that association with respect to congenital malformations ("neonatal defects" mentioned in the Book of Poker). In the autism paper, researchers identified the location of the New Jersey Super Fond Fund sites and approximately 500 children diagnosed from 1998 to 2006 and found that the cases appeared more frequently near the sites. These researchers also verified a relationship between larger numbers of superfund sites in a state and the frequency of ASD uses. This analysis "appears significant overlap" between the high rates of superfinancing and the diagnosis of autism - although authors quickly warned that the association did not mean that one caused the other. The 2014 paper looked at births from 1989 to 2003, near the Superfund sites in Florida, Michigan, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Texas - each cleaned up at some point within that time frame. Before the site was cleaned, on average, infants were likely to have a birth defect of between 20 and 25 per cent. According to Janet Corrie, a writer and professor of economics and public affairs at Princeton University, in an e-mail to KHN. Both are longitudinal studies, which means that research has been collected over time to track patterns and changes. The poker formulation is entirely deliberate - an important issue for his case, namely, the verification of the facts mentioned by Kirk Cox in a speech delivered on 13 January 2021. Virginia ranked lowest third of the states in the management of the COVID-19 vaccine. • On January 20, 2012, we spoke to researchers in environmental health who were not linked to studies. They said it would be very difficult to prove that the birth near the Superfond site caused the birth of children with congenital defects, or caused autism. It would be helpful if Poker did not try to prove it in his statements. However, one caution is that a normal listener can draw this conclusion. The studies with which he works are "fair exploration," said David Savitz, Professor of Epidemiology at the Faculty of Public Health at Brown University. While it supports the idea of a link between autism and Superfund sites, or congenital defects and such sites, it does not go so far as to support the cause of causation. There are other factors that can also contribute. "It's not hard to imagine all the ways that communities close to different waste sites may be -- a lot of ways other than just having a waste site," said Savitz. However, poker comments are rooted in legitimate data sources. Both studies are peer-reviewed and suggest some kind of relationship. Therefore, his claim centre - there are data showing that children near the Superfond sites have higher rates of congenital abnormality and autism - is actually investigating this. However, environmental health experts said that more work was needed to understand the nature of that allegation. The risk factors for autism are still not well defined. Congenital abnormalities can also refer to a range of different problems, so research that brings them together can mask important differences, especially when it comes to what may cause a particular birth defect. The experts said that the bigger picture of poker came to a greater reality: many of the chemicals found at the Superfond sites were related to health problems. These same experts added that its environmental justice framework is also logical, given the demographic characteristics of those who are often affected. From a policy point of view, Savitz argued that the biggest point of poker - that cleaning up big boxes would improve health outcomes, especially for marginalized people - was clearly correct. The only real issue some have suggested is using the word "dramatic." The data indicate a potential relationship, but whether "dramatic" is far from clear. "Sure there's evidence to support his claim," said Amanda Packian, Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at Utah University, who studies environmental contributors to the danger of autism. "There was work to create a bond, but the relationship is modest. We need more research in this area." Our assessment of poker is correct in saying the data shows that children born near superfund have higher rates of congenital defects and autism. In this statement, he does not say specifically that there is a causal relationship - an important one, because the data do not necessarily indicate that the proximity of SuperFund causes those issues, and further research will be required to support this claim. The use of the word "dramatic" causes some problems, however. Data sets show statistically significant linkages. But this isn't the same thing as a "dramatically higher rate." The statement is correct, but it could be used in more context. We're mostly assessing it right. This fact-finding was reported and edited by the Kaiser Health News.
